vocabInfos.lsjDefs:
ἑορτ-ή,
in Ionic dialect Prose ὁρτή (so [Refs 5th c.BC+], probably in Ion Trag.21, but ἑορτή [Refs 6th c.BC+], ἡ, feast, festival, holiday, ἐπεὶ καὶ πᾶσιν ἑ. [Refs 8th c.BC+]; ὁρτὴν ἄγειν keep a feast,[Refs 5th c.BC+]
__2 generally, holiday-making, amusement, pastime, παιδιᾶς καὶ ἑορτῆς χάριν [Refs 5th c.BC+]
__3 proverbial, κατόπιν ἑορτῆς ἥκειν to have come the day after the fair, [Refs 5th c.BC+]; ἀεργοῖς αἰὲν ἑορτά every day's a holiday to those who don't work, [Refs 3rd c.BC+]
__4 assembled multitude at a festival, ὄχλος καὶ ἑ. καὶ στρατὸς καὶ πλῆθος [Refs 3rd c.AD+]
vocabInfos.shortDef: feast, festival, in the NT this refers the joyous gathering of people for the celebrations of the Jewish calendar year, having a focus on ceremonial eating, such as Passover, Pentecost, and New Moon
vocabInfos.mediumDef:
feast, festival, in the NT this refers the joyous gathering of people for the celebrations of the Jewish calendar year, having a focus on ceremonial eating, such as Passover, Pentecost, and New Moon
a solemn feast, public festival, Lk. 2:41; 22:1; Jn. 13:1; specifically used of the passover, Mt. 26:5; 27:15
